meaning_mnemonic: Even though you’ve <radical>old</radical> <radical>legs</radical>, you <kanji>overcome</kanji> your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!

The <radical>mole</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> ready for your <kanji>arrival</kanji>. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.
If you have one <radical>stool</radical> and another <radical>stool</radical>, you have a <kanji>pair</kanji> of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.

Wrap your <radical>fingers</radical> around this <radical>axe</radical> and put it in your <radical>mouth</radical> to express your <kanji>philosophy</kanji>. Your philosophy of… putting axes in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, but by doing this you're showing them that it's not!
Under the <radical>cross</radical> is a <radical>mouth</radical> and another <radical>mouth</radical> wearing special <radical>clothes</radical> because they're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>.

A <radical>servant</radical> secures a <radical>stool</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> so that it is a <kanji>solid</kanji> sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!

Someone's <radical>fingers</radical> touch your <radical>tongue</radical> and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.
Using a <radical>bow</radical>, shoot a <radical>melon</radical> and it will fly in a steep <kanji>arc</kanji>. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.
When your <radical>fingers</radical> move like that, you know it's an <radical>omen</radical> of a <kanji>challenge</kanji> that will face you soon in the future.

You see <radical>fingers</radical> on a <radical>flag</radical> by the <radical>exit</radical>, indicating that you should <kanji>dig</kanji>. The fingers on the flag point downward, just by the exit, as if to say "dig here!" There must be something under here. That's what you think to yourself as you start to dig with your fingers.
If you have <radical>fingers</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to <kanji>hoist</kanji> things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.
You use your <radical>fingers</radical> in a <radical>shop</radical> to <kanji>grip</kanji> what you want to buy.

With your <radical>fingers</radical>, you grab a <radical>satellite</radical> and <kanji>shake</kanji> it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong enough for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.

Use <radical>simultaneous</radical> <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to perform the <kanji>purification</kanji> ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)

To your <radical>car</radical> you take an <radical>axe</radical>. The <radical>sun</radical> has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that <kanji>temporarily</kanji>. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.

You hit a <radical>tree</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical> so you can do some <kanji>analysis</kanji> on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.
In the <radical>tree</radical> <radical>district</radical> of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need <kanji>hinge</kanji>s.
A <radical>car</radical> works for one <radical>reason</radical>: its wheels can spin on an <kanji>axis</kanji>. Yep, that lateral axis is definitely a car's most <kanji>pivotal part</kanji>.

You walk up to a <radical>tree</radical> and put <radical>dynamite</radical> on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful <kanji>pattern</kanji> into the side of it as well as the ground around it.

The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical> is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place <kanji>overnight</kanji>, without even asking!

A <radical>tsunami</radical> breaks your <radical>bone</radical>s, not from hitting you, but from making you <kanji>slide</kanji> and <kanji>slip</kanji> into stuff. Hard to keep your footing in a tsunami, you know? You're slipping and sliding all over the place.

A <radical>tsunami</radical> crashes into the <radical>sun</radical> (breaking it in half) and creating a different <radical>wing</radical> of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a <kanji>lagoon</kanji>.
You take a <radical>turkey</radical> and try to <radical>boil</radical> it but you <kanji>char</kanji> it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.

This <radical>bamboo</radical> can be whittled into an <kanji>example</kanji> of anything. See, here's a <radical>car</radical>. Here's a <radical>snake</radical>. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.
Take this <radical>thread</radical> and look at this <radical>part</radical>. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have <kanji>distract</kanji>ed you!
<radical>Thread</radical> and <radical>vines</radical> alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to <kanji>twist</kanji> them together to make them strong.

If you take a <radical>thread</radical> and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a <radical>hill</radical> of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a <kanji>rope</kanji>.

You see a <radical>thread</radical>-covered <radical>hill</radical>, but it's all lumpy and weird. You approach it to take a closer look, and you see it's actually a huge <kanji>net</kanji> with a bunch of stuff caught in it: fish, cats, tree branches. All this random stuff is what's making the net look so lumpy!
If the <radical>moon</radical> is <radical>dry</radical>, it's good for your <kanji>liver</kanji>! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
There are <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>hills</radical> in your front <kanji>lawn</kanji>. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.

<radical>Flowers</radical> find their <radical>death</radical> in a <radical>river</radical> out in the <kanji>wild</kanji>. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
You keep your <radical>substitute</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> in a <kanji>sack</kanji>. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
What do you <radical>eat</radical> if you’re wearing <radical>horns</radical> and surrounded by <radical>lantern</radical>s? <kanji>Mochi</kanji> (or <kanji>sticky rice cake</kanji>s) of course!
<radical>Shellfish</radical> cause <radical>landslide</radical>s because of all their <kanji>bustling</kanji> and <kanji>lively</kanji> underwater activity.
